docs.snippet: 8 P.M. (National Geographic) HITLER'S SUICIDE SHIP  This is the story of one of Hitler's prized warships, the Admiral Graf Spee, above, which was blown up by its own captain, Hans Langsdorff, in December 1939 after a battle with British ships off the...
docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (National Geographic) HITLER'S SUICIDE SHIP This is the story of one of Hitler's prized warships, the Admiral Graf Spee, above, which was blown up by its own captain, Hans Langsdorff, in December 1939 after a battle with British ships off the coast of Uruguay. Though the Graf Spee was more technologically advanced and had heavier artillery, Langsdorff tried to win by evading opponents instead of attacking. He then committed suicide. ''Gestapo Chief,'' at 9, follows the husband-and-wife team Serge and Beate Klarsfeld as they search for Nazis and try to bring them to justice. Kurt Lischka, once the Gestapo chief in Paris and responsible for the deaths of tens of thousands of Jews, was allowed to live openly in West Germany instead of paying for his crimes. The couple shadowed Lischka for almost nine years and eventually planned a kidnapping that ended in the couple's arrest in 1974. On ''Hunting Hitler's Generals,'' at 10, Allied operatives are ordered to capture or kill Gen. Erwin Rommel in his Libyan desert headquarters. Something went horribly wrong during the mission, and what really happened is still a mystery. 8 P.M. (Fox) HELL'S KITCHEN In the eighth season of this reality competition the chef Gordon Ramsay remains stunned by what he views as his contestants' incompetence.

docs.snippet: The ING Group announced on Monday that it would sell its Latin American insurance unit to Grupo de Inversiones Suramericana for $3.9 billion, as the Dutch financial firm looks to shed assets to comply with the terms of its government bailout.
docs.lead_paragraph: The ING Group announced on Monday that it would sell its Latin American insurance unit to Grupo de Inversiones Suramericana for $3.9 billion, as the Dutch financial firm looked to shed assets to comply with the terms of its government bailout.

headline.main: ING to Sell Latin American Insurance Unit for $3.9 Billion

docs.snippet: Uruguay claimed its record 15th Copa América championship on Sunday, beating Paraguay decisively in the final, 3-0, and reinforcing its claim as the best team in South America.
docs.lead_paragraph: Uruguay claimed its record 15th Copa América championship on Sunday, beating Paraguay decisively in the final, 3-0, at the Estadio Monumental in Buenos Aires and reinforcing its claim as the best team in South America. Luis Suárez scored Uruguay’s first goal — his fourth of the tournament — and Diego Forlán added two for the champions.
docs.abstract: Uruguay claimed its record 15th Copa América championship on Sunday, beating Paraguay decisively in the final, 3-0, and reinforcing its claim as the best team in South America.

headline.main: Copa América: Uruguay Tops Paraguay in Final

docs.snippet: When Diego Forlán led Uruguay to victory on Sunday, he became the third generation of his family to win the in the Copa América.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Diego Forlán led Uruguay to victory on Sunday, he became the third generation of his family to win the in the Copa América.

headline.main: For Diego Forlán, the Copa América Runs in the Family
headline.print_headline: For Diego Forlán, the Copa América Runs in the Family

docs.snippet: Venezuela was the surprise team of the recently completed Copa América.
docs.lead_paragraph: Copa América in Argentina is over, Uruguay has taken home the trophy for the 15th time, and the rest of South America assesses whether the balance of soccer power has been altered. If so, the net winner is Venezuela, which was eliminated in the semifinals, on penalty kicks against Paraguay, without having lost a match.
docs.abstract: Venezuela was the surprise team of the recently completed Copa América.

docs.snippet: The amazing adventures of the black seaman William Tillman.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Aug. 3, 1861, Harper’s Weekly published the astounding account of William Tillman, a 27-year old African-American sailor born a free man in Delaware. Tillman had been on the crew of the Yankee merchantman the S. J. Waring. On July 6 the 300-ton schooner, manned by a crew of eight under the command of Captain Francis Smith, had left New York bound for Montevideo, Uruguay, with a cargo of foodstuffs and a single passenger. Three days into its voyage, the ship was captured by a Confederate privateer, the Jefferson Davis.
docs.abstract: The amazing adventures of the black seaman William Tillman.
